CYBL, Cylinder balancing coordination at DC
12.17.4.15.3 Readiness via AD cycles
// detection of finished adaptation cycles at range low adaptation
IF (1) STATE_ER_BAL_HOM = "CYLINDER BALANCING" [3H] and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_L_ENA = 1 and
NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[0](n) <> NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[0](n-1)
THEN (1) NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[0] = NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[0] +1
NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[0] = NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[0] +1
// detection of adaptation readiness in case of maximum number of
adaptation cycles reached
IF (2) NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[0] > C_NR_CYC_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) LV_FAC_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC = 1
ENDIF (2)
// setting of time gap after several range low adaptation cycles in
row
IF (2) NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[0] >
C_NR_CYC_RNG_L_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) T_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC = C_T_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC
T_WAIT_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC = C_T_WAIT_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC
NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[0] = 0[-]
ENDIF (2)
// detection of finished adaptation cycles at range high adaptation
ELSEIF (1) STATE_ER_BAL_HOM = "CYLINDER BALANCING" [3H] and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_H_ENA = 1 and
NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[1](n) <> NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[1](n-1)
THEN (1) NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[1] = NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[1] +1
NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[1] = NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[1] +1
// detection of adaptation readiness in case of maximum number of
adaptation cycles reached
IF (2) NR_CYC_BAL_HOM_DC[1] > C_NR_CYC_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) LV_FAC_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC = 1
ENDIF (2)
// setting of time gap after several range high adaptation cycles in
row
IF (2) NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[1] >
C_NR_CYC_RNG_H_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) T_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC = C_T_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC
T_WAIT_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC = C_T_WAIT_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC
NR_CYC_RNG_BAL_HOM_DC[1] = 0
ENDIF (2)
ENDIF (1)

CYBL, Cylinder balancing coordination at DC
12.17.4.15.4 Readiness via AD quality
// detection of AD readiness at minimum spreading of adaptation values
IF(1) STATE_ER_BAL_HOM = "CYLINDER BALANCING" [3H]
AND
(NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[0](n) <> NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[0](n-1) or
NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[1](n) <> NR_CYC_AD_DC_BAL_HOM[1](n-1))
THEN(1) FAC_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC = 0
FAC_COR_MV_BAL_HOM_DC =
SUM(i=0:1:NC_CYL_NR-1,FAC_COR_BUF_TMP_ER_BAL_HOM[i])/NC_CYL_NR
FOR (2) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
IF | FAC_COR_BUF_TMP_ER_BAL_HOM[i] - FAC_COR_MV_BAL_HOM_DC| >
FAC_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN FAC_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC =
|FAC_COR_BUF_TMP_ER_BAL_HOM[i] - FAC_COR_MV_BAL_HOM_DC|
ENDIF
END FOR (2)
IF (2) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_L_ENA = 1 and
FAC_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC < C_FAC_COR_DIF_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[0] = NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[0] +1
IF (3) NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[0] >
C_NR_MAX_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (3) LV_FAC_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC = 1
ENDIF (3)
ELSEIF (2) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_H_ENA = 1 and
FAC_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC < C_FAC_COR_DIF_MAX_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (2) NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[1]= NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[1] +1
IF (3) NR_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC[1] >
C_NR_MAX_COR_DIF_BAL_HOM_DC
THEN (3) LV_FAC_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC = 1
ENDIF (3)
ENDIF (2)
ENDIF (1)
12.17.4.15.5 Out of range conditions
// calculation of limited dynamic and out of range for adaptation condition
IF LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_L_ENA = 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_H_ENA = 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA = 0
THEN T_RNG_NOT_BAL_HOM_DC = T_RNG_NOT_BAL_HOM_DC + 0.1[s]
ELSE T_RNG_NOT_BAL_HOM_DC = 0.0[s]
ENDIF

CYBL, Cylinder balancing coordination at DC
12.17.4.15.6 Adaptation exit condition
// reset of adaptation condition for exit at state adaptation
IF ( T_TMP_BAL_HOM_DC ? C_T_MIN_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_ACK = 0)
OR
T_TMP_BAL_HOM_DC ? C_T_MAX_RNG_TOT_BAL_HOM_DC
OR
T_RNG_NOT_BAL_HOM_DC ? C_T_MAX_RNG_NOT_BAL_HOM_DC
OR
(LV_FAC_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC = 1 and
LV_FAC_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC = 1 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 )
OR
(T_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC > 0.0[s] and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 )
OR
(LV_FAC_RNG_L_BAL_HOM_DC = 1 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_L_ENA = 1 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 )
OR
(LV_FAC_RNG_H_BAL_HOM_DC = 1 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_H_ENA = 1 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 )
OR
(LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0 and
LV_INH_ER_BAL_PRI_MNG = 1 )
OR
(LC_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_MNG_DC = 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 1 and
LV_INH_ER_BAL_PRI_MNG = 1 )
OR
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG(n) <> LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG(n-1)
THEN
IF LV_T_STEP_BAL_HOM_DC = 0
THEN LV_ER_BAL_HOM_REQ_IT = 0
ENDIF
ENDIF
12.17.4.16 State "Adaptation" - Exit
Transition to State 0[H] ?Wait? (Time out)
// Cylinder balancing driving cycle manager request for change of state
IF LV_STATE_CHG_WAIT_BAL_HOM_DC = 1
Transition to State 1[H] ?Request? (Condition 3)
// conditions for cylinder balancing homogenous not achieved
IF ( LV_ER_BAL_HOM_REQ_IT = 0 or LV_ER_BAL_HOM_ECU_ENA = 0)
Assignments at exit from state ?Adaptation?:
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_REQ_IT = 0
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_CDN = 0
T_TMP_BAL_HOM_DC = 0.0[s]

� General Information
The objective of cylinder balancing diagnosis is monitoring the output of cylinder balancing via engine rough-
ness in homogenous engine operation mode. Breaking the diagnosis limits for several adaptation cycles,
which may have been caused by malfunctioning components, shall be diagnosed by cylinder balancing diag-
nosis. The failure allocation is cylinder selective. Should the anti bounce counter of any cylinder be over the
maximum threshold, the concerned cylinder has to be detected as defect.

� General Information
� Application Conditions

� Function Description
12.18.2.1 Action de?nition: ACTION_CYBL_GetCdnDiagPre
// at action call the following calculations are performed
IF(1) ( PRM_AD_RANGE == 0[H] and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 0] == 0 ) or
( PRM_AD_RANGE== 1[H] and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 1] == 0 ) or
( PRM_AD_RANGE== 2[H] and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 2] == 0 )
THEN(1)
FOR(2) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
IF(3) CLF_IDX_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM[bit position i] == PRM_AD_BANK
THEN(3) // calculation of predicted adaptation values
LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_PRE[bit position i] = 1
IF(4) //ghost counter operation not activated
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_PRI_DIAG = 0
THEN(4) //calculation of AD values for pre diagnosis
FAC_COR_PRE_DIAG_BAL_HOM[i] =
PRM_FAC_AD_PRE[i] +
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_L_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 0] ) +
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_H_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 1] )+
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_IS_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 2] )
ELSE(4) //calculation of old AD values for pre diagnosis
FAC_COR_PRE_DIAG_BAL_HOM[i] =
PRM_FAC_AD_PRE[i] +
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_L_OLD_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 0] ) +
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_H_OLD_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 1] )+
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_IS_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM
[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit position 2] )
ENDIF(4)
ENDIF(3)
ENFOR(2)
ENDIF(1)

// at action call the following calculations are performed
IF(1) ( PRM_AD_RANGE == 0[H] and

THEN(1)

THEN(3) // calculation of confirmed adaptation values
LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_AD[bit position i] = 1
// calculation of adaptation values for diagnosis
FAC_COR_AD_DIAG_BAL_HOM[i] =
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_L_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit 0]) +
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_H_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit 1])+
(FAC_COR_AD_RNG_IS_ER_BAL_HOM[i] *
LF_FAC_COR_AD_RNG_MOD_BAL_HOM[PRM_AD_RANGE][bit 2])
ENDIF(3)
ENFOR(2)
ENDIF(1)

12.18.3 Cylinder imbalance diagnosis
� General Information
Description of cylinder imbalance diagnosis more in detail will be done at next speci?cation update. Thank
you for your understanding.
� Application Conditions
Activation: LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP = 0
Deactivation: LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP = 1
Recurrence: SYS_EVE__100MS
� Function Description
Cylinder imbalance diagnosis - out of range
// basic cylinder balancing out of range diagnosis condition
IF(1) LV_INH_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM = 0 and
LV_ST_END = 1 and
[ LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_PRE <> 0[H] or
LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_AD <> 0[H] ]
THEN(1)
// cylinder balancing out of range diagnose possible
FOR(2) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
12.18.3.1 Conditions ? out of range
// adaptation conditions for out of range diagnosis
IF(3) LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_PRE[bit position i] == 1 or
LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_AD[bit position i] == 1
THEN(3)
// increment of adaptation cycle counter
NR_CYC_AD_DIAG_BAL_HOM[i] ++
ENDIF(3)
12.18.3.2 Diagnosis of adaptation values
// adaptation values out of range check
IF(3) LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_AD[bit position i] == 1
THEN(3)
// condition flags for adaptation value diagnosis
LV_CDN_DIAG_ER_BAL_AD_MAX[i] = 1
LV_CDN_DIAG_ER_BAL_AD_MIN[i] = 1
// adaptation values out of maximum range check
IF(4) FAC_COR_AD_DIAG_BAL_HOM[i] >
C_FAC_AD_OBD_MAX_POS_BAL_HOM[i]
// adaptation values out of maximum range detected

LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_DIAG[i] = 1
//setting of diagnosis ERR index
ELSE(2) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_DIAG[i] = 0
ENDIF(2)
ENDFOR(1)
FOR(1) m = 0 to NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM - 1
IF(2) CTR_DIAG_ERR_BAL_HOM_RBM[m] > 0 or
CTR_DIAG_END_BAL_HOM_RBM[m] ==
(NC_CYL_NR / NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM)
THEN(2) LV_END_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM_RBM[m] = 1
ENDIF(2)
ENDFOR(1)

CYBL, Cylinder balancing diagnostics (Appl. Inc.)
12.19.2 Diagnostics (Appl. Inc.) ? 100MS task
� General Information
The Appl. Inc. module is used to keep the cylinder balancing functions modular. Therefore the inhibit condition
for the cylinder balancing- and the cylinder balancing diagnosis function are calculated within this module. The
corresponding functions are inhibit as soon and as long as the inhibit ?ag is enabled.
� Application Conditions
Activation: LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP = 0
Deactivation: LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP = 1
Recurrence: 100MS
� Function Description
12.19.2.1 Inhibition of Cylinder balancing diagnosis
Inhibit condition for cylinder balancing diagnosis function
IF LV_FID_READY = 1
THEN ACTION_FARM_GetPermission
(IN<NC_FID_ERR_ER_BAL_HOM_A>,OUT<PRM_LV_PRMS_A>)
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission
(IN<NC_FID_ERR_ER_BAL_HOM_B>,OUT<PRM_LV_PRMS_B>)
ELSE PRM_LV_PRMS_A = 0
PRM_LV_PRMS_B = 0
ENDIF
IF { PRM_LV_PRMS_A = 1 and
PRM_LV_PRMS_B = 1 and
LC_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DIAG = 0 }
OR
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 0] = 1
THEN LV_INH_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM = 0
ELSE LV_INH_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM = 1
ENDIF
12.19.2.2 Inhibition of balancing function
Bank specific inhibit condition for cylinder balancing adaptation function
FOR m = 0 to NC_CBK_EX_NR - 1
IF ( STATE_CAT_DIAG[m] == END (4H) or
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 8] = 1 )
AND
(STATE_CAT_DIAG[m] == END (4H) or
[
STATE_CAT_DIAG[m] == PASSIVE (0H) and
{
LV_CAT_DIAG_GAP_ENA_CP = 1 or
STATE_CP(n) = "RAMP_CLOSE" (BH) or
STATE_CP(n) = "RAMP_TO_NO_PURGE" (2H) or
(STATE_CP(n) == "NO_PURGE" (1H) and
STATE_CP(n-1) <> "NO_PURGE" (1H) )
}
] or
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 7] = 1 )
File: 30B0A803.00F
3939Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
CYBL, Cylinder balancing diagnostics (Appl. Inc.)
AND
(STATE_DYN_DIAG[m] == END (3H) or
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 6] = 1 )
AND
(LV_DLY_END_LSL_DIAG[m] = 1 or
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 5] = 1 )
AND
(STATE_T_SDL_CP <> LAM_FIXED (2H) or
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 2] = 1 )
THEN LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM_CBK[m] = 0
ELSE LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM_CBK[m] = 1
ENDIF
ENDFOR
Inhibit condition for cylinder balancing adaptation function
IF {
LV_INH_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM = 0 AND
TAM >= C_TAM_MIN_INH_ER_BAL_HOM AND
AMP >= C_AMP_MIN_INH_ER_BAL_HOM AND
[
SUM(i=0:1:NC_CBK_EX_NR-1,LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM_CBK[i])=0 or
(LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT = 1 and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 4] = 0) or
(LV_T_STEP_BAL_HOM_DC = 1 and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 3] = 0)
]
}
OR
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_INH_DEAC[bit position 1] = 1
THEN LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM = 0
ELSE LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM = 1
ENDIF
// Annotation: SUM(i=0:1:NC_CBK_EX_NR-1,LV_INH_ER_BAL_HOM_CBK[i])=0 means:
// all NC_CBK_EX_NR number of inhibit flags must be set to zero
12.19.3 Interface for Rate ? Based ? Monitoring
� General Information
With this module the interface between the ER_BAL_HOM monitor and the Rate-Based Monitoring statistics is
de?ned with STATE_RBM_ER_BAL_HOM[NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM] data.
Within STATE_RBM_ER_BAL_HOM[NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM], three different information are de?ned:
? Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
(no intrusive operation, no short trip)
? Monitor disabled because of system malfunction (bit 1)
(depending on failure status: pending)
? Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this DC (bit 2)
Please note, the function cylinder balancing diagnosis is working cylinder individual, while the calculation of the
rate based monitoring interface is calculated dependent on number of cylinder banks for cylinder balancing
(NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM).
� Application Conditions

CYBL, Cylinder balancing diagnostics (Appl. Inc.)
12.19.3.1 New monitor evaluation or monitor inhibition removal by ERRM
General information:
This Action is called by ERRM aggregate each time:
- a new evaluation of rate-based monitoring data for this monitor is required.
or
- monitor inhibition shall be removed (bit 1 = 0) because Mode $04 was called (ERRM data cleared)
- ACTION_CYBL_IniRbmClcErBalHom(IN <PRM_TYP_INI>, IN <PRM_NR_CONF>)
This action is called by ERRM aggregate to force a new evaluation of rate-based monitoring data of diagnosis
or to remove rate-based monitoring inhibition related to system fault.
Formula section:
If PRM_TYP_INI = ?REST?
Then
bit 0, bit 1 and and bit 2 of STATE_RBM_ER_BAL_HOM[PRM_NR_CONF] = 0
Else
//(PRM_TYP_INI = ?CLR?)//
bit 1 of STATE_RBM_ER_BAL_HOM[PRM_NR_CONF] = 0
Endif

sis" function used for cylinder imbalance monitoring as requested by legislation. In case monitoring is delayed

CYBL, Cylinder balancing mis?re diagnostics
by mis?re events appearing during running cylinder balancing at the current lean shifted cylinder, the actual
lean-shift is stopped at once. After a short waiting time the lean shift is carried out again at the same cylinder.
This procedure will be repeated until a successful cylinder lean shift is available or a maximum number of tried
lean shits is reached.
Cylinder imbalance monitoring is delayed by mis?re events during active cylinder balancing. In case the
mis?re rate is increasing, the needed diagnosis time for imbalance monitoring is increasing as well. At a special
mis?re rate imbalance monitoring is not able to ?nish diagnosis within active driving cycle and the mis?re
monitor does not detect mis?re because the mis?re rate is still to low. In this case the cylinder balancing
mis?re diagnosis must be able to indicate this behaviour.
For a description more in detail please refer to below function principal. At this example a three cylinder engine
is used for explanation:
Figure 12.20.1:
Adaptation cycle one - lean shift without mis?re events
After a successful lean shift of all cylinders the cylinder balancing adaptation values are calculated the ?rst time
and the ?rst adaptation cycle is ?nished as well. At this adaptation cycle no mis?re events occur and the single
cylinders are lean shifted sequentially in a special order as de?ned by calibration. The mis?re counters show
no action and remain zero.
Adaptation cycle two - lean shift with mis?re event at tested and not tested cylinder
The second adaptation cycle starts again with lean shift of cylinder one. During lean shift a mis?re event occurs
at actual test cylinder one. In this case the actual lean shift is stopped at once and the mis?re counter for
cylinder one is increased. The second try for lean shifting of cylinder one shows exactly the same behaviour.
Finally at third try a successful lean shift of cylinder one occurs and the mis?re counter for cylinder one is
decreased.
Next lean shift is carried out for cylinder two. During lean shift mis?re occurs as well, but this time the mis?re
event is not present at actual tested (lean shifted) cylinder two, it occurs at not tested cylinder one. Mis?re

CYBL, Cylinder balancing mis?re diagnostics
events at not tested cylinders are ignored and do not interrupt the actual lean shift. Cylinder two is working
well and lean shift is successful ?nished as usual. The mis?re counter for cylinder two remains zero.
This adaptation cycle is ?nished with a successful lean shift of cylinder three with following calculation of
cylinder balancing adaptation values.
Adaptation cycle three - mis?re event at test cylinder
At beginning of third adaptation cycle the ?rst two cylinders are lean shifted with success and without any
mis?re occurrence. Because the value of mis?re counter for cylinder one is not equal to zero, the counter is
decreased after cylinder one is ?nished.
During lean shift of cylinder three mis?re occurs at the actual tested cylinder. As a consequence, the lean shift
is stopped immediately and mis?re counter for cylinder three is increased. At the following repeat no mis?re
event is present and lean shift of cylinder three is ?nished without trouble. In this case the mis?re counter for
cylinder three is decreased and the adaptation cycle is ?nished with a new calculation of cylinder balancing
adaptation values.
Adaptation cycle four - mis?re event at test cylinder with failure entry
The ?nal adaptation cycle, which will not be ?nished completely, starts with lean shift of cylinder one again.
Mis?re events at cylinder one occur within the ?rst lean shift loop as well as the repeat loop. As soon as the lean
shift is interrupted, the mis?re counter for cylinder one is increased. After the repeat loop the mis?re counter
is exceeding the maximum threshold for failure detection.
A cylinder imbalance mis?re failure cylinder one is entered within error management and the diagnosis end
?ag is set. As soon as a failure is detected, regardless on which cylinder, all mis?re counters are initialized to
zero. Cylinder imbalance monitoring in combination with cylinder imbalance mis?re monitoring is ?nished for
the actual driving cycle.

CYBL, Cylinder balancing mis?re diagnostics
12.20.3.1 Mis?re counter reset during monitoring
IF(1) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END = 0
THEN(1)
//reset of misfire counter based on cylinder misfire failure
FOR(2) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
IF(3) //imbalance cylinder misfire monitoring error detected
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_MIS_CYL[i] == 1
THEN(3)
//reset of cylinder misfire counter
FOR(4) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[i] = 0
ENDFOR(4)
//reset of summary misfire counter
CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM = 0
ENDIF(3)
ENDFOR(2)
//reset of misfire counter based on summary misfire failure
IF(2) //imbalance summary misfire monitoring error detected
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_MIS_SUM == 1
THEN(2) //reset of cylinder misfire counter
FOR(3) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[i] = 0
ENDFOR(3)
//reset of summary misfire counter
CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM = 0
ENDIF(2)
ENDIF(1)
12.20.3.2 Mis?re counter end condition check
IF(1) CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 3] == 0 or
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END = 0
//misfire counter end condition not yet achieved
THEN(1)
//calculation of misfire diagnosis end condition
IF(2) [ CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 0] == 0 and
SUM(i=0:1:NC_CYL_NR-1,...
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_END_MIS_CYL[i]) = NC_CYL_NR ]
OR
[ CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 0] == 0 and
SUM(i=0:1:NC_CYL_NR-1,...
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_MIS_CYL[i]) <> 0 ]
OR
[ CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 1] == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_END_MIS_SUM = 1 ]
OR
[ CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 1] == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_ERR_MIS_SUM = 1 ]
THEN(2) //misfire counter end condition reached
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END = 1
LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS = 0000 [H]
ELSE(2) //misfire counter end condition not yet reached
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END = 0
//reset of cylinder misfire counter diagnosis conditions

FOR(3) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
IF(4) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_END_MIS_CYL[i] = 1
THEN(4) LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS[bit position i] = 0
ENDIF(4)
ENDFOR(3)
//reset of summary misfire counter diagnosis conditions
IF(3) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_IDX_END_MIS_SUM = 1

ENDIF(2)

12.20.3.3 Mis?re counter increment
IF(1) //lean shift deactivation based on misfire at active cylinder
[ LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END == 0 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM(n-1) == 0 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM(n) == 1 ]
OR
[ LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END == 1 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM(n-1) == 0 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM(n) == 1 and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 8] == 0 ]
THEN(1) //cylinder misfire counter increment (max value limited to FFFF)
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] =
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] +
C_CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_INC_BAL_HOM
//calculation of summary misfire counter

THEN(2)

CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] >
C_CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_MAX_BAL_HOM
THEN(2) LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS[bit position NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] = 1

CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM > C_CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_MAX_BAL_HOM

12.20.3.4 Mis?re counter decrement
IF(1) //lean shift finished with success at active cylinder
[ LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END == 0 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM == 0 and
STATE_ER_BAL_HOM == "Cylinder Balancing" [3H] and
NR_CYL_BAL_HOM[IDX_BAL_HOM](n) <>
NR_CYL_BAL_HOM[IDX_BAL_HOM](n-1) ]
OR
[ LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT == 0 and
LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END == 1 and
LV_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM == 0 and
STATE_ER_BAL_HOM == "Cylinder Balancing" [3H] and
NR_CYL_BAL_HOM[IDX_BAL_HOM](n) <>
NR_CYL_BAL_HOM[IDX_BAL_HOM](n-1) and
CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 9] == 0 ]
THEN(1)//cylinder misfire counter decrement (minimum value limited to zero)
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] =
CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[NR_SEG_BAL_HOM] -
C_CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_DEC_BAL_HOM
//calculation of summary misfire counter
IF(2) CLF_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_DEAC[bit position 2] == 0
THEN(2)
CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM = 0
FOR(3) i = 0 to NC_CYL_NR - 1
CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM =
CTR_MIS_DIAG_SUM_BAL_HOM + CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[i]
ENDFOR(3)
ELSE(2)
FOR(3) m = 0 to NC_NR_CBK_BAL_HOM - 1
IF(4) NR_CBK_BAL_HOM[m][IDX_BAL_HOM](n) <
NR_CBK_BAL_HOM[m][IDX_BAL_HOM](n-1)
THEN(4)
//setting of bank index value for finished AD loop

12.20.4.1 Cylinder mis?re counter imbalance monitoring
//cylinder imbalance misfire monitoring of cylinder specific misfire
IF(1) LV_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_DIAG_END = 0 and
LV_INH_DIAG_ER_BAL_HOM = 0 and

LF_ERR_CDN_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS <> 0 and

THEN(3) //setting of condition flag for misfire diagnosis

CTR_MIS_DIAG_CYL_BAL_HOM[i] >

(IN<LV_SYM_BAL_HOM_MIS_CYL[i]>,

IN<1>,

THEN(4) ACTION_ERRM_Record
(IN<NC_IDX_ERR_ER_BAL_HOM_MIS_CYL[i]>,
IN<STATE_FIL_BAL_HOM_MIS_CYL[i]> )
ENDIF(4)
ENDIF(3)

## Function
The primary function of this diagram, as indicated by the title "CYBL Cylinder balancing via additive mass fuel flow intervention," is to implement a control strategy for balancing engine cylinders by intervening with additive mass fuel flow. It calculates and manages the necessary fuel adjustments based on various engine parameters and error signals to ensure smooth and efficient cylinder operation. The "Signal Manager" acts as the central logic unit, integrating initialization, operational data, and external inputs to determine the final balancing adjustments and diagnostic limits.

## Inputs
1.  **Function Call / Control Signals:**
    *   `fc_INI`: Function call signal to trigger the initialization routine.
    *   `fc_OPM_SEG`: Function call signal to trigger the main operating segment routine.
2.  **System/Status Inputs (Green Blocks):**
    *   `<FR_STND_MMV_DIF_BAL>`: (Frame Standard Minimum Mean Value Difference Balancing) - Likely represents a calculated cylinder imbalance error or difference.
    *   `<LV_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_ENA>`: (Local Variable Mass Fuel Flow Additive Error Balancing Enable) - A boolean signal to enable/disable additive mass fuel flow balancing.
    *   `<SEQ_NR_ER>`: (Sequence Number Error) - Possibly a counter or indicator related to sequence errors.
    *   `<NC_CYL_NR>`: (Number of Cylinders Number) - The number of active engine cylinders.
    *   `<LV_TL_ER_BAL_ACT>`: (Local Variable Tolerance Error Balancing Actual) - The actual tolerance value for balancing error.
    *   `<LV_MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL_ENA>`: (Local Variable Mass Fuel Flow Additive Adaptation Error Balancing Enable) - A boolean signal to enable/disable adaptation of additive balancing.
    *   `<N>`: (Engine Speed) - Engine rotational speed.
    *   `<T_AST_BAL>`: (Temperature After Start Balancing) - Engine temperature relevant for balancing, possibly after engine start.
    *   `<MFF_SP_MV>`: (Mass Fuel Flow Setpoint Measured Value) - The measured or target mass fuel flow setpoint.
3.  **Internal Feedback Signals:**
    *   `[feedback]` (to INI X.1): Feedback signal for the initialization sub-system.
    *   `[feedback]` (to OPM_SEG X.2): Feedback signal for the operating segment sub-system.

## Outputs
1.  **Balancing Control Outputs (Blue Blocks):**
    *   `<LV_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_OBD_MAX_NEG>`: (Local Variable Mass Fuel Flow Additive Error Balancing OBD Maximum Negative) - The maximum allowed negative additive fuel flow for OBD monitoring of balancing.
    *   `<LV_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_OBD_MAX_POS>`: (Local Variable Mass Fuel Flow Additive Error Balancing OBD Maximum Positive) - The maximum allowed positive additive fuel flow for OBD monitoring of balancing.
    *   `<MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL>`: (Mass Fuel Flow Additive Adaptation Error Balancing) - The calculated adaptive additive mass fuel flow adjustment for cylinder balancing. This is a primary control output.
    *   `<MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_EXT>`: (Mass Fuel Flow Additive Error Balancing Extended/External) - An extended or externally used version of the additive mass fuel flow error for balancing.
2.  **Internal Feedback Signal:**
    *   `[feedback]` (from Signal Manager): A feedback signal from the Signal Manager, likely representing internal state or status for other parts of the system.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to **initialize a comprehensive set of parameters for a Cylinder Balancing (CYBL) system**. This initialization process involves gathering various inputs, including current feedback values, system configuration (number of cylinders), and persistent data stored in Non-Volatile Memory (NVM). All these parameters are then aggregated into a single output bus, ready for use by the main CYBL control logic.

## Inputs

The key inputs to this initialization subsystem are:

1.  **`fc_ini`**: An event or boolean signal that triggers the overall initialization process, typically indicating a system startup or reset.
2.  **`MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL` (from `feedback1` port 3)**: A feedback signal representing an additive mass fuel flow adjustment value for cylinder balancing, likely from a previous operating state or a default. This value is also passed to the NVM storage block.
3.  **`NC_CYL_NR` (from `input` port 2)**: The number of cylinders in the engine, a fundamental system configuration parameter.
4.  **`fc_NVMini`**: A function-call or enable signal to trigger the reading of initial non-volatile memory data.
5.

This value is also passed to the NVM storage block.
3.  **`NC_CYL_NR` (from `input` port 2)**: The number of cylinders in the engine, a fundamental system configuration parameter.

5.  **`fc_NVMRES`**: A function-call or enable signal to trigger the reading of non-volatile memory data typically used after a reset or for recovery.
6.  **`fc_NVMSTO`**: A function-call or enable signal to trigger the reading (or potentially writing, depending on implementation details of `fc()`) of stored non-volatile memory data.

## Outputs

The primary output is a single bus named **`ini`**, which encapsulates all the initialized parameters. The components of this bus are:

*   `NR_CYC_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_MAX` (number of cycles for maximum control value)

## Logic Flow

The initialization process follows these steps:

1.  **Triggering Initialization**: The `fc_ini` signal (connected to `fc_RST`) activates the main `RST` subsystem (X.1.1), initiating the core initialization logic. Simultaneously, dedicated function-call signals (`fc_NVMini`, `fc_NVMRES`, `fc_NVMSTO`) can activate the NVM read operations.

2.  **Gathering Inputs**:
    *   The `RST` block receives the feedback value `MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL` from the `feedback1` port and the engine's `NC_CYL_NR` from the `input` port.

3.  **Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) Retrieval**:
    *   The `NVMini` (X.1.2) block, when triggered by `fc_NVMini`, reads an initial or default value for `MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL` from NVM and outputs it as `nvmini`.
    *   The `NVMRES` (X.1.3) block, when triggered by `fc_NVMRES`, reads a reset or recovery value for `MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL` from NVM and outputs it as `nvmres`.
    *   The `NVMSTO` (X.1.4) block, triggered by `fc_NVMSTO`, processes the `MFF_ADD_AD_ER_BAL` feedback. It reads a stored value from NVM, but its output is not directly merged into the final `ini` bus in this diagram.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to implement a **Cylinder Balancing** strategy by calculating an **additive mass fuel flow intervention** for individual engine cylinders. It uses a feedback control loop to adjust the fuel supplied to each cylinder (`[x]`) based on its detected imbalance, aiming to minimize the difference in combustion or torque output across cylinders. The system incorporates proportional (P) and integral (I) control elements, a dead zone for filtering small errors, and saturation limits for the final correction.

## Inputs

1.  **`ER_STND_MMV_DIF_BAL[x]` (In1)**: This is the primary input representing the **standardized measured mean value difference for balance** for a specific cylinder `[x]`. It signifies the detected imbalance or deviation for that cylinder, likely derived from crankshaft acceleration or other combustion quality metrics.
2.  **`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL[x]` (In2)**: This input represents the **previous or current additive mass fuel flow balance correction** applied to cylinder `[x]`. It acts as a feedback or initial condition for the adjustment process.
3.  **`IP_MFF_ADD_P_ER_BAL`**: This is an **interpolation parameter or characteristic map for the proportional component** of the additive mass fuel flow. It defines how the proportional correction (`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_P`) is calculated based on the effective imbalance.
4.  **`IP_MFF_ADD_I_ER_BAL`**: This is an **interpolation parameter or characteristic map for the integral component** of the additive mass fuel flow. It defines how the integral correction (`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_I[x]`) is calculated based on the effective imbalance.

## Outputs

1.  **`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL[x]` (Out1)**: This is the **calculated and limited additive mass fuel flow balance correction** for cylinder `[x]`.

It defines how the integral correction (`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_I[x]`) is calculated based on the effective imbalance.

## Outputs

1.  **`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL[x]` (Out1)**: This is the **calculated and limited additive mass fuel flow balance correction** for cylinder `[x]`. This output is the final fuel flow adjustment to be applied to the cylinder's base fuel quantity, and it also feeds back as an input for the next control cycle.

*Note: `[x]` in the signal names denotes a placeholder for the specific engine cylinder or segment number (e.g., SEG_NR_ER), indicating that this logic is applied per cylinder.*

## Logic Flow

The logical flow calculates an updated additive mass fuel flow correction for each cylinder `[x]` through the following steps:

1.  **Imbalance Signal Filtering (Dead Zone):**
    *   The incoming imbalance signal `ER_STND_MMV_DIF_BAL[x]` is first passed through a **"Dead Zone"** block. This block effectively ignores very small imbalance values (within a specified range around zero), preventing the controller from reacting to minor fluctuations or noise, which helps to improve stability and avoid unnecessary control actions.
    *   The output of the Dead Zone is `ER_STND_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL`, representing the significant imbalance that requires correction.

2.  **Proportional (P) Control Component Calculation:**
    *   The effective imbalance `ER_STND_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL` is fed into a function generator (represented by `f(x)`), which uses the `IP_MFF_ADD_P_ER_BAL` characteristic. This block computes the **proportional control component** `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_P`. This component generates a correction directly proportional to the current imbalance error, providing immediate response.

3.  **Integral (I) Control Component Calculation:**
    *   In parallel, the effective imbalance `ER_STND_MFF_ADD_ER_BAL` is fed into another function generator (represented by `f(x)`), which uses the `IP_MFF_ADD_I_ER_BAL` characteristic. This block computes the **integral control component** `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_I[x]`. This component accumulates past errors over time, allowing the controller to eliminate steady-state errors and bring the system to the desired balance point over time.

4.  **Combined Control Action:**
    *   The proportional component (`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_P`) and the integral component (`MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL_I[x]`) are summed together. The output of this summation is `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL`, representing the total newly calculated control action based on the current and accumulated imbalance.

5.  **Existing Correction Adjustment:**
    *   The previously applied additive fuel flow correction `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL[x]` (Input In2) is passed through an **"Adjustment"** block (labeled `f(u)`). This block likely applies a dynamic scaling, filtering, or other conditioning to the existing correction, producing `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_COR[x]`. This step prepares the historical correction for integration with the new control action.

6.  **Summation for New Additive Flow:**
    *   The adjusted existing correction `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_COR[x]` is then summed with the newly calculated total control action `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_CTL`.
    *   The result of this summation is `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_LIM[x]`, which represents the raw, unconstrained new additive fuel flow correction for cylinder `[x]`.

7.  **Output Limiting (Saturation):**
    *   Finally, `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL_LIM[x]` passes through a **"Saturation"** block. This block limits the additive fuel flow correction to a predefined minimum and maximum range. This is crucial for preventing unphysical or undesirable fuel flow values that could harm the engine or negatively impact its operation.
    *   The output of the Saturation block is the final `MFF_ADD_ER_BAL[x]` (Output Out1), which is then applied to the cylinder's fuel injection and fed back into the system for the next iteration.

## Function
This Simulink diagram describes a "Master slave system" for "Cylinder balancing signal preparation." Its primary function is to compute reference values for cylinder balancing (`NR_SEG_BAL_REF`, `ER_BAL_REF`, `ER_DRV1_BAL_REF`) based on various error states and a segment number. The logic implements a conditional selection (if-elseif structure) to determine these reference values based on the parity of `SEG_NR_ER` and the state of `LV_ECU_SLA`.

## Inputs
*   **`SEG_NR_ER`**: Segment Number Error (Boolean or integer, typically representing an error code or status for a segment).
*   **`LV_ECU_SLA`**: Low Voltage ECU Slave (Boolean, indicating a low voltage state or error for a slave ECU).
*   **`ER`**: General Error (Boolean or integer, representing a general error status).
*   **`DRV1_ER`**: Driver 1 Error (Boolean or integer, representing an error status for Driver 1).
*   **`LV_ENA_ER`**: Low Voltage Enable Error (Boolean, indicating a low voltage state related to an enable signal).

## Outputs

*   **`ER_BAL_REF`**: Error Balancing Reference (Value, likely passed through or calculated based on general error).

## Logic Flow

The system operates based on a primary conditional structure (similar to an `if-elseif-else` statement), which selects different calculations to generate the balancing reference outputs.

1.  **Evaluate First Condition (If Block):**
    *   **Condition 1 Calculation**:
        *   `SEG_NR_ER` is subjected to a modulo `2` operation (`SEG_NR_ER mod 2`). This checks if `SEG_NR_ER` is even or odd.
        *   The result of the modulo operation is compared to `0` (`(SEG_NR_ER mod 2) == 0`). This evaluates to `TRUE` if `SEG_NR_ER` is even.
        *   `LV_ECU_SLA` is inverted using a `NOT` gate.

    *   **If Condition 1 is TRUE**:

        *   These three candidate values are then passed to respective `Merge` blocks via a `V.5.2` block (likely an output port of the conditional subsystem or a pass-through switch).

2.  **Evaluate Second Condition (Elseif Block):**
    *   If the first condition was `FALSE`, the system proceeds to evaluate the `elseif` branch.
    *   **Condition 2 Calculation**:
        *   `SEG_NR_ER` is subjected to a modulo `2` operation (`SEG_NR_ER mod 2`).
        *   The result is compared to `1` (`(SEG_NR_ER mod 2) == 1`). This evaluates to `TRUE` if `SEG_NR_ER` is odd.
        *   The input `LV_ECU_SLA` is used directly (not inverted).

*   **Condition 2 Calculation**:
        *   `SEG_NR_ER` is subjected to a modulo `2` operation (`SEG_NR_ER mod 2`).
        *   The result is compared to `1` (`(SEG_NR_ER mod 2) == 1`). This evaluates to `TRUE` if `SEG_NR_ER` is odd.
        *   The input `LV_ECU_SLA` is used directly (not inverted).
        *   The results of `((SEG_NR_ER mod 2) == 1)` and `LV_ECU_SLA` are combined using an `AND` gate. This forms the second logical condition for the `cond_if` block.
    *   **If Condition 2 is TRUE (and Condition 1 was FALSE)**:
        *   `NR_SEG_BAL_REF` candidate: `SEG_NR_ER` is incremented by `1` (`SEG_NR_ER + 1`), then the result is divided by `2` (`(SEG_NR_ER + 1) / 2`).
        *   `ER_BAL_REF` candidate: The input `ER` is directly passed through.
        *   `ER_DRV1_BAL_REF` candidate: The input `DRV1_ER` is directly passed through.
        *   These three candidate values are then passed to respective `Merge` blocks via a `V.5.2` block.

3.  **Default Case (Else Block - Implicit):**
    *   If neither Condition 1 nor Condition 2 is `TRUE`, an implicit `else` path is taken. The diagram does not explicitly show the calculations for this `else` branch, but the `Merge` blocks ensure that a value is always produced for each output. In Simulink conditional subsystems, if an `else` branch is not explicitly defined, outputs might hold their previous values, default to zero, or draw from an input defined for the `else` case, or if the `V.5.2` blocks are switches, they would select another input. The `LV_ENA_ER` and `LV_ENA_ER_BAL` inputs, though present, are not explicitly connected to the conditional logic shown to determine the `BAL_REF` outputs in the depicted `if`/`elseif` branches.

4.  **Output Merging:**
    *   For each of the three output signals (`NR_SEG_BAL_REF`, `ER_BAL_REF`, `ER_DRV1_BAL_REF`), a `Merge` block is used. These blocks combine the values from the active conditional branch (either `if`, `elseif`, or implicit `else`) to produce the final output values. This ensures that the outputs always receive a value from the currently active logical path.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the diagram can be broken down into the following steps:

1.  **Determine Homing State:**
    *   The `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP` boolean input is passed through a `NOT` block.
    *   The inverted signal controls an `If` block (`V.6.0`), which in turn governs the activation of two mutually exclusive execution paths or "action ports," labeled `[fcn_1]` and `[fcn_2]`.
    *   If `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP` is `FALSE` (homing is active), the `NOT` block outputs `TRUE`, activating the `[fcn_1]` path.
    *   If `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP` is `TRUE` (homing has stopped), the `NOT` block outputs `FALSE`, activating the `[fcn_2]` path.

2.  **Calculate Delay Index Balance (Conditional):**
    *   **When Homing is Active (`[fcn_1]` path):** The `CLC_DLY_IDX_BAL` block (X.2.2.1) executes. It takes `input` and `feedback` signals to calculate or update a `DLY_IDX_BAL` (Delay Index Balance). This likely involves accumulating or processing values relevant to the balancing index during the homing phase.
    *   **When Homing has Stopped (`[fcn_2]` path):** The `CLC_DEC_DLY_IDX_BAL` block (X.2.2.2) executes. It takes the current `DLY_IDX_BAL_cur` as input and calculates a decremented `DLY_IDX_BAL`. This suggests that after homing, the balance index might be gradually reduced or reset.

3.  **Select Current `DLY_IDX_BAL`:**
    *   A Multiport Switch block (`V.6.1`, near the output) selects between the `DLY_IDX_BAL` calculated by `CLC_DLY_IDX_BAL` (X.2.2.1) and the `DLY_IDX_BAL` from `CLC_DEC_DLY_IDX_BAL` (X.2.2.2).
    *   The control signal for this switch is derived from the initial homing state (similar to how `[fcn_1]` and `[fcn_2]` are activated), ensuring that the correct `DLY_IDX_BAL` (either updated or decremented) is selected based on `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_STOP`.

4.  **Feedback `DLY_IDX_BAL_cur`:**
    *   The selected `DLY_IDX_BAL` from the Multiport Switch (`V.6.1`) is fed back into the system. It becomes `DLY_IDX_BAL_cur`, which serves as the "current" delay index balance for subsequent calculations (especially for the `CLC_DEC_DLY_IDX_BAL` block and the error standard calculation).

5.  **Calculate Cylinder Balancing Error Standard:**
    *   In parallel with the delay index balance calculation, the `CLC_CRLC_ER_STND_BAL` block (X.2.2.3) takes `DLY_IDX_BAL_cur` (the feedback value from step 4) and `input1` to calculate the "Cylinder Balancing Error Standard". This represents a measure of error or deviation in the cylinder balancing.

6.  **Final Constant Determination:**
    *   The selected `DLY_IDX_BAL` (from step 3) and the "Cylinder Balancing Error Standard" (from step 5) are summed together.
    *   The result of this summation then passes through a limiter block (indicated by the trapezoidal symbol), which enforces minimum and/or maximum bounds on the value.
    *   The final, limited value is output as `adj_fil_c`, which is the `ADJ_FIL_C` (Adjustable Filter Constant).

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and track misfire-related variables during an active lean shift operation in an automotive system. Specifically, it counts misfire events detected during the lean shift, compares this count against a predefined maximum threshold, and updates a "confirmed" misfire counter if the threshold is exceeded. This mechanism supports decision-making, such as stopping the lean shift ramp if misfires become excessive.

## Inputs

1.  **`f(t)` (Block labeled "fc")**: An event or signal indicating a misfire detection. This block `IDM_BAL_HOM` likely acts as a trigger when a misfire is detected.
2.  **`idx_bal_hom`**: An index or identifier, likely representing a specific cylinder or a balancing group for which misfire data is being processed. It's used to access indexed data.
3.  **`CTR_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM`**: The current number of misfires detected (but not yet necessarily "confirmed") for the current active lean shift, specific to `idx_bal_hom`. This is an input value that gets updated internally.
4.  **`C_NR_MIS_MAX_DET_BAL_HOM`**: A calibrated constant representing the maximum allowed number of detected misfires during an active lean shift for the given index before a condition is met (e.g., stopping the lean shift).
5.  **`CTR_MIS_DET_CFM_BAL_HOM`**: The current number of "confirmed" misfires. This is a global or aggregated counter that increments when the misfire threshold condition is met. This is an input value that gets updated internally.
6.  **`1` (Constants V.6.11, V.6.11)**: Used as an increment value in sum blocks.

## Outputs

The diagram outputs a multiplexed signal named `out` containing the following four components:

1.  **`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`**: The updated number of misfire events detected within the current active lean shift range, specific to the `idx_bal_hom`.
2.  **`[fcn1]`**: A boolean flag or signal indicating that the detected misfire count (`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`) has met or exceeded the calibrated maximum threshold (`C_NR_MIS_MAX_DET_BAL_HOM`). This likely triggers an action such as stopping the lean shift ramp.
3.  **`[fcn2]`**: A boolean flag or signal indicating that the detected misfire count (`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`) is still below the calibrated maximum threshold (`C_NR_MIS_MAX_DET_BAL_HOM`).
4.  **`CTR_MIS_DET_CFM_BAL_HOM`**: The updated number of "confirmed" misfires. This counter increments only when the `[fcn1]` condition (misfire threshold exceeded) is true.

## Logic Flow

The diagram processes misfire detection events through three main parallel or sequential logic paths:

1.  **Tracking Detected Misfires (`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`)**:
    *   A misfire detection event, likely represented by the `IDM_BAL_HOM` signal (derived from `f(t)`), initiates this path.
    *   The current detected misfire count for the relevant index (`CTR_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM` accessed via `idx_bal_hom` in block V.6.16) is retrieved.

**Tracking Detected Misfires (`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`)**:
    *   A misfire detection event, likely represented by the `IDM_BAL_HOM` signal (derived from `f(t)`), initiates this path.
    *   The current detected misfire count for the relevant index (`CTR_MIS_DET_BAL_HOM` accessed via `idx_bal_hom` in block V.6.16) is retrieved.
    *   This retrieved count is incremented by `1` using a Sum block (V.7.7).
    *   The updated count is then stored as `NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM` (block V.7.16), representing the running tally of misfires for the current active lean shift and index.

    *   The updated detected misfire count (`NC_NR_RNG_BAL_HOM`, specifically the output from Sum block V.7.7) is compared with the calibrated maximum misfire threshold (`C_NR_MIS_MAX_DET_BAL_HOM` accessed via `idx_bal_hom` in block V.6.11).
    *   A Relational Operator block (`>=`, V.6.6) checks if the detected misfire count is greater than or equal to the maximum allowed.

    *   If the condition is true (misfire count >= threshold), the `[fcn1]` output is activated.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and manage segment counter values to detect a "limited dynamics" condition for each segment (e.g., cylinder) in a cylinder balancing system. It essentially implements a set of per-segment countdown timers: when a segment's counter is positive, it indicates an active "limited dynamics" state and the counter decrements. When the counter reaches zero, the "limited dynamics" state for that segment is reset, and the counter is reloaded with a new baseline value.

The system processes segment counter values iteratively. The `ForIterator` subsystem, detailed in Figure 12.14.22, performs the core logic for each segment.

**Overall Flow (Figure 12.14.21):**

6.  The `CTR_SEG_LDC_ER_BAL_HOM_out` is fed back as an input to the overall system (`feedback` port), making the segment counters stateful across execution cycles.

## Function

The primary function of this system is to manage the coordination of cylinder balancing in an automotive direct current (DC) system, likely within an engine management unit (EMU). It orchestrates a process involving waiting for conditions, requesting balancing adaptation, and then executing the adaptation itself. The system uses a state machine to control the sequence of operations and relies on various inputs and internal flags to make decisions about initiating, maintaining, and concluding the balancing process. The accompanying logic defines how requests for balancing and fixed-time step operations are generated and controlled based on system states, diagnostic conditions, and timing parameters.

## Inputs

*   **Condition 1, Condition 2, Condition 3:** Undefined logical conditions that drive transitions between the "Wait", "Request", and "Adaptation" states. These conditions are typically composed of multiple system signals.
